security: The document is marked TOP SECRET UMBRA/DINAR, indicating it contains highly sensitive compartmented information. Sharing details of diplomatic communications and reactions to President Kennedy's assassination could harm international relations and reveal sensitive intelligence gathering methods.
summary: This report details Washington's concern over a Cambodian broadcast that appeared to celebrate the deaths of perceived enemies, including a possible allusion to President Kennedy, prompting diplomatic demarches.
summary_one_paragraph: On December 12, 1963, this TOP SECRET report relays concerns from Washington regarding a Cambodian radio broadcast that seemed to celebrate the deaths of 'enemies of Cambodia,' including Diem and Sarit, with wording that implied a similar fate for a 'big boss,' possibly alluding to President Kennedy's assassination. Ambassador Yost informed NONG KIMNY of the State Department's shock at this 'barbaric declaration,' requesting a public disavowal of any allusion to Kennedy's death; the U.S. government planned demarches in both Phnom Penh and Washington to express their dismay, while awaiting further instructions.
title: 3/0/CED/T214-63: WASHINGTON CONCERNED OVER CAMBODIAN BROADCAST
